_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Nursery, Garden Center, and Farm Supply Stores

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Accidental Release Prevention Program

The management and employees of this Crop Production Service facility are committed to the prevention of any release of chemicals handled at this facility.  If a release should occur, this facility is prepared to work with the local hazardous materials team, the local fire department, the local administering agency, and our emergency response contractor to control, contain and clean up the release.

2. Facility Information

The primary activity at this facility is the storage and sale of liquid and dry fertilizers and pre-packaged and bulk agricultural chemicals to growers and ranchers.

This facility stores and handles two regulated chemicals - Anhydrous Ammonia and Aqua Ammonia.  Anhydrous Ammonia is used for direct field application by growers as a fertilizer.  It is also used at this facility for the production of Aqua Ammonia.

Aqua Ammonia is produced and stored at the facility.  It is used for direct field application by growers as a fertilizer.

3. Worst-Care Release Scenario and Alternative Release Scenarios

The facility prepared a worst-case and alternative release scenarios.  These are not included in the Executive Summary as recommended by EPA.

4. Accidental Release Prevention Program

This facility operates in accordance with the following regulations:

- National Electrical Code
- Uniform Fire Code
- ANSI K61.1 Safety Requirements for Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia
- Title 8, California code of Regulations (CCR) Subchapter 1, Unfired Pressure Vessel Safety Orders
- Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.111 Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia
- Title 29 CFR 1920.38 Employee Emergency Response Plan and Fire Prevention Plans
- Title 29 CFR 1910.120 Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response
- Title 40 CFR Part 68 Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions
- Title 19 CCR Division 2 Chapter 4.5 California Accidnetal Release Prevention (CalARP) Program

5. Five-year Accident History

There have been no accidental releases of Anhydrous Ammonia or Aqua Ammonia at this facility during the past five years

6. Emergency Response Program

This facility has prepared and implemented an emergency response plan that meeds state and federal regulations.  The emergency response plan specifies the lines of authority and the roles and responsibilities individuals are to assume during an emergency.  The emergency response plan includes procedures to follow for fires, explosions, medical emergencies, spills, releases and natural disasters such as earthquakes and flooding.

7. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Safety improvements are an on-going process at this facility.  Improvements to existing safety procedures and practices are determined through inspections and audits that are conducted periodically.
